trans-unit.source: How to Use the Engagement API on iOS
trans-unit.target: How to Use the Engagement API on iOS

trans-unit.source: Latest iOS SDK - How to Use the Engagement API on iOS
trans-unit.target: Latest iOS SDK - How to Use the Engagement API on iOS

trans-unit.source: This document is an add-on to the document How to Integrate Engagement on iOS: it provides in depth details about how to use the Engagement API to report your application statistics.
trans-unit.target: This document is an add-on to the document How to Integrate Engagement on iOS: it provides in depth details about how to use the Engagement API to report your application statistics.

trans-unit.source: Keep in mind that if you only want Engagement to report your application's sessions, activities, crashes and technical information, then the simplest way is to make all your custom UIViewController objects inherit from the corresponding EngagementViewController class.
trans-unit.target: Keep in mind that if you only want Engagement to report your application's sessions, activities, crashes and technical information, then the simplest way is to make all your custom UIViewController objects inherit from the corresponding EngagementViewController class.

trans-unit.source: If you want to do more, for example if you need to report application specific events, errors and jobs, or if you have to report your application's activities in a different way than the one implemented in the EngagementViewController classes, then you need to use the Engagement API.
trans-unit.target: If you want to do more, for example if you need to report application specific events, errors and jobs, or if you have to report your application's activities in a different way than the one implemented in the EngagementViewController classes, then you need to use the Engagement API.

trans-unit.source: The Engagement API is provided by the EngagementAgent class.
trans-unit.target: The Engagement API is provided by the EngagementAgent class.

trans-unit.source: An instance of this class can be retrieved by calling the [EngagementAgent shared] static method (note that the EngagementAgent object returned is a singleton).
trans-unit.target: An instance of this class can be retrieved by calling the [EngagementAgent shared] static method (note that the EngagementAgent object returned is a singleton).

trans-unit.source: Before any API calls, the EngagementAgent object must be initialized by calling the method [EngagementAgent init:@"Endpoint={YOUR_APP_COLLECTION.DOMAIN};SdkKey={YOUR_SDK_KEY};AppId={YOUR_APPID}"];
trans-unit.target: Before any API calls, the EngagementAgent object must be initialized by calling the method [EngagementAgent init:@"Endpoint={YOUR_APP_COLLECTION.DOMAIN};SdkKey={YOUR_SDK_KEY};AppId={YOUR_APPID}"];

trans-unit.source: The following parts refine the common <linkText>Mobile Engagement Concepts</linkText><title></title> for the iOS platform.
trans-unit.target: The following parts refine the common <linkText>Mobile Engagement Concepts</linkText><title></title> for the iOS platform.

trans-unit.source: An activity is usually associated with one screen of the application, that is to say the activity starts when the screen is displayed and stops when the screen is closed: this is the case when the Engagement SDK is integrated by using the EngagementViewController classes.
trans-unit.target: An activity is usually associated with one screen of the application, that is to say the activity starts when the screen is displayed and stops when the screen is closed: this is the case when the Engagement SDK is integrated by using the EngagementViewController classes.

trans-unit.source: But activities can also be controlled manually by using the Engagement API.
trans-unit.target: But activities can also be controlled manually by using the Engagement API.

trans-unit.source: This allows to split a given screen in several sub parts to get more details about the usage of this screen (for example to known how often and how long dialogs are used inside this screen).
trans-unit.target: This allows to split a given screen in several sub parts to get more details about the usage of this screen (for example to known how often and how long dialogs are used inside this screen).

trans-unit.source: You need to call startActivity() each time the user activity changes.
trans-unit.target: You need to call startActivity() each time the user activity changes.

trans-unit.source: The first call to this function starts a new user session.
trans-unit.target: The first call to this function starts a new user session.

trans-unit.source: You should NEVER call this function by yourself, except if you want to split one use of your application into several sessions: a call to this function would end the current session immediately, so, a subsequent call to startActivity() would start a new session.
trans-unit.target: You should NEVER call this function by yourself, except if you want to split one use of your application into several sessions: a call to this function would end the current session immediately, so, a subsequent call to startActivity() would start a new session.

trans-unit.source: This function is automatically called by the SDK when your application is closed.
trans-unit.target: This function is automatically called by the SDK when your application is closed.

trans-unit.source: Session events are usually used to report the actions performed by a user during his session.
trans-unit.target: Session events are usually used to report the actions performed by a user during his session.

trans-unit.target: Example without extra data:

trans-unit.target: Example with extra data:

trans-unit.source: Contrary to session events, standalone events can be used outside of the context of a session.
trans-unit.target: Contrary to session events, standalone events can be used outside of the context of a session.

trans-unit.source: Example:
trans-unit.target: Example:

trans-unit.source: Session errors are usually used to report the errors impacting the user during his session.
trans-unit.target: Session errors are usually used to report the errors impacting the user during his session.

trans-unit.source: Example:
trans-unit.target: Example:

trans-unit.source: Contrary to session errors, standalone errors can be used outside of the context of a session.
trans-unit.target: Contrary to session errors, standalone errors can be used outside of the context of a session.

trans-unit.source: Example:
trans-unit.target: Example:

trans-unit.source: Errors can be related to a running job instead of being related to the current user session.
trans-unit.target: Errors can be related to a running job instead of being related to the current user session.

trans-unit.source: Example:
trans-unit.target: Example:

trans-unit.source: Suppose you want to report an error during your login process:
trans-unit.target: Suppose you want to report an error during your login process:

trans-unit.source: Events can be related to a running job instead of being related to the current user session.
trans-unit.target: Events can be related to a running job instead of being related to the current user session.

trans-unit.source: Example:
trans-unit.target: Example:

trans-unit.source: Suppose we have a social network, and we use a job to report the total time during which the user is connected to the server.
trans-unit.target: Suppose we have a social network, and we use a job to report the total time during which the user is connected to the server.

trans-unit.source: The user can receive messages from his friends, this is a job event.
trans-unit.target: The user can receive messages from his friends, this is a job event.

trans-unit.source: Arbitrary data can be attached to events, errors, activities and jobs.
trans-unit.target: Arbitrary data can be attached to events, errors, activities and jobs.

trans-unit.source: This data can be structured, it uses iOS's NSDictionary class.
trans-unit.target: This data can be structured, it uses iOS's NSDictionary class.

trans-unit.source: Note that extras can contain arrays(NSArray, NSMutableArray), numbers(NSNumber class), strings(NSString, NSMutableString), urls(NSURL), data(NSData, NSMutableData) or other NSDictionary instances.
trans-unit.target: Note that extras can contain arrays(NSArray, NSMutableArray), numbers(NSNumber class), strings(NSString, NSMutableString), urls(NSURL), data(NSData, NSMutableData) or other NSDictionary instances.

trans-unit.source: The extra parameter is serialized in JSON.
trans-unit.target: The extra parameter is serialized in JSON.

trans-unit.source: If you want to pass different objects than the ones described above, you must implement the following method in your class:
trans-unit.target: If you want to pass different objects than the ones described above, you must implement the following method in your class:

trans-unit.source: The method should return a JSON representation of your object.
trans-unit.target: The method should return a JSON representation of your object.

trans-unit.source: Each key in the NSDictionary must match the following regular expression:
trans-unit.target: Each key in the NSDictionary must match the following regular expression:

trans-unit.source: ^[a-zA-Z][a-zA-Z_0-9]*
trans-unit.target: ^[a-zA-Z][a-zA-Z_0-9]*

trans-unit.source: It means that keys must start with at least one letter, followed by letters, digits or underscores (\_).
trans-unit.target: It means that keys must start with at least one letter, followed by letters, digits or underscores (\_).

trans-unit.source: Extras are limited to 1024 characters per call (once encoded in JSON by the Engagement agent).
trans-unit.target: Extras are limited to 1024 characters per call (once encoded in JSON by the Engagement agent).

trans-unit.source: In the previous example, the JSON sent to the server is 58 characters long:
trans-unit.target: In the previous example, the JSON sent to the server is 58 characters long:

trans-unit.source: You can manually report tracking information (or any other application specific information) using the sendAppInfo: function.
trans-unit.target: You can manually report tracking information (or any other application specific information) using the sendAppInfo: function.

trans-unit.source: Note that these information can be sent incrementally: only the latest value for a given key will be kept for a given device.
trans-unit.target: Note that these information can be sent incrementally: only the latest value for a given key will be kept for a given device.

trans-unit.source: Like event extras, the NSDictionary class is used to abstract application information, note that arrays or sub-dictionaries will be treated as flat strings (using JSON serialization).
trans-unit.target: Like event extras, the NSDictionary class is used to abstract application information, note that arrays or sub-dictionaries will be treated as flat strings (using JSON serialization).

trans-unit.source: Example:
trans-unit.target: Example:

trans-unit.source: Each key in the NSDictionary must match the following regular expression:
trans-unit.target: Each key in the NSDictionary must match the following regular expression:

trans-unit.source: ^[a-zA-Z][a-zA-Z_0-9]*
trans-unit.target: ^[a-zA-Z][a-zA-Z_0-9]*

trans-unit.source: It means that keys must start with at least one letter, followed by letters, digits or underscores (\_).
trans-unit.target: It means that keys must start with at least one letter, followed by letters, digits or underscores (\_).

trans-unit.source: Application information are limited to 1024 characters per call (once encoded in JSON by the Engagement agent).
trans-unit.target: Application information are limited to 1024 characters per call (once encoded in JSON by the Engagement agent).

trans-unit.source: In the previous example, the JSON sent to the server is 44 characters long:
